properties.name: Athabasca-Redwater
properties.description: Posted by JournalwebteamAfter 19 often-tumultuous years in office, Mike Cardinal (PC) is saying goodbye. But voters still have familiar names to choose from. Tory candidate and odds-on favourite Jeff Johnson (PC) is trying to take after dad LeRoy Johnson, the retiring Wetaskiwin-Camrose MLA, while Bill Bonko is the Liberal. Yep, the son of Bill Bonko, Liberal MLA in neighbouring Edmonton-Decore.

properties.name: Chinatown
properties.description: Posted by JournalwebteamChinatown is one of my favourite places because it is an adventure of exotic sights, tastes and experiences. Read more

properties.name: Clue #1
properties.description: Posted by Journalwebteam1) The new Matrix Hotel on 107th St. and 10oth Ave. is a breathe of fresh air — the renovation of a run-down hotel property into a hip neo-modernist gem. The lobby features a tall, sleek fireplace, complete with a cool waterfall. But can you tell me — what is the fireplace made from?

properties.name: Clue #10
properties.description: Posted by JournalwebteamEdmonton architect Gene Dub, who also designed our City Hall, recently won an urban design award for his glassy new housing development on 97th Street, right behind Canada Place. The apartment complex is built above a former Edmonton landmark. What was this site in its earlier life?

properties.name: Clue #11
properties.description: Posted by JournalwebteamThe Lodge Hotel and the Ernest Brown Block, on 96th St. and Jasper Ave., are being turned into an new museum and archives celebrating the history of Alberta’ Ukrainian community. According to the sign on the building, when did the Ernest Brown Block open?

properties.name: Clue #2
properties.description: Posted by JournalwebteamThe northwest corner of Jasper Ave. and 104th St., the former site of the Cecil Hotel, is a busy construction zone. A handsome new office and retail block will be opening soon, with a Sobey’s grocery store as its anchor tenant. What firm of architects is designing the building? And what does the Sobey’s block have in common with the old Birks Building across the street?

properties.name: Clue #3
properties.description: Posted by JournalwebteamJust north of the Sobey’s site (Jasper Ave. and 104th St) Langham Properties is building two condominium towers. What is that condo project called — and according to the placard on the property, what lofty record will the tower set?

properties.name: Clue #4
properties.description: Posted by JournalwebteamThe Bay LRT station, which was all but a ghost station for many years, is suddenly busy again. If you haven’t been there in awhile, get reacquainted with it. And tell me —what cool colour are the brick tiles that line the station walls?

properties.name: Clue #5
properties.description: Posted by JournalwebteamThe old Hudson’s Bay Building has a new life as Enterprise Square, the downtown campus of the University of Alberta. When you walk in the entry doors on 102nd Ave., one of the first offices you pass is the Office of Alumni Affairs. Peek in the office window and you’ll see a large green and gold crest hanging on the wall. What does the crest read — and what does it mean?

properties.name: Clue #6
properties.description: Posted by JournalwebteamThe U of A is sharing its space with the Art Gallery of Alberta, while the gallery awaits its new building. One of the AGA’s current exhibitions is a show called Fun House. Please name three of the Canadian artist whose works are included in the exhibit.

properties.name: Clue #7
properties.description: Posted by JournalwebteamWith apologies to the Village People — it’s fun to play at the YMCA. Drop by the new Don Wheaton Family Y, at 102nd Ave. and 102nd Street, and tell me this. For what family is the Y’s aquatic centre named?

properties.name: Clue #8
properties.description: Posted by JournalwebteamFor years, the ornate Hop’s Handbags building on Jasper Avenue sat vacant, a symbol of everything wrong with our downtown core. This fall, the old red Hop’s sign finally came down, and new tenants filled the building. Can you name one of the businesses that now occupies that space?

properties.name: Clue #9
properties.description: Posted by JournalwebteamThe new art gallery, designed by architect Randall Stout, is under construction at the northeast end of Churchill Square. Tell me — what colour is the construction crane on that site?

properties.name: Commodore Restaurant
properties.description: Posted by Journalwebteam The Commodore has a lunch counter with twirly stools, a candy display by the cash register and a Hamilton Beach milkshake mixer. Read more

properties.name: Commonwealth Stadium
properties.description: Posted by JournalwebteamCommonwealth Stadium is one of my favourite places because of its old-school virtues -- because its name wasn\'t prostituted to some bland financial institution, insurance giant or multinational corporation. Read more

properties.name: Dunvegan-Central Peace
properties.description: Posted by JournalwebteamIn a rare nail-biter in the Tory-loving countryside, Hector Goudreau squeezed through by 341 votes over the Alliance\'s Dale Lueken. For round two, Goudreau expects his campaigners will be less complacent, and that his new cred as a cabinet minister can help sway voters. But Lueken has been in non-stop campaign mode, stirring up the anti-PC mood in this vast but sparsely populated riding.

properties.name: Dwayne Roger Roy
properties.description: Posted by JournalwebteamVictim: Dwayne Roger Roy, 57Date: July 30, 2007Location: Royal Alexandra HospitalAccused: Jean Francois Sheehy, 34, has been charged with second-degree murderRead more

properties.name: Earth's General Store
properties.description: Posted by JournalwebteamEarth\'s General Store is one of my favourite places in Edmonton. It is one of my favourite places because it reminds me of the angel on my right shoulder. Read more

properties.name: Edmonton Centre
properties.description: Posted by JournalwebteamAfter three straight failures, the Tories have stopped running retired professor Don Weideman in the city1s core against Liberal stalwart Laurie Blakeman. This time, they1re fielding consultant Bill Donahue, while the NDP have inner-city teacher Deron Bilous.

properties.name: Edmonton City Hall
properties.description: Posted by JournalwebteamScott McKeen thinks City Hall is so cool that it\'s one of his favourite places in Edmonton. Read more

properties.name: Edmonton-Beverly-Clareview
properties.description: Posted by JournalwebteamRay Martin, the NDP1s former leader, won easily last time to end his 11-year legislature hiatus. But this may become a three-way race. Tony Vandermeer, ex-Tory MLA in nearby Edmonton-Manning, wants back in, too. Liberal Dawit Isaac, an Eritrea-born evangelical church leader, has dazzled fellow Grits with his organizing prowess.

properties.name: Edmonton-Calder
properties.description: Posted by JournalwebteamDavid Eggen (NDP) worked the neighbourhoods hard to win in 2004, and hasn1t stopped since. Safety manager Doug Elniski (PC) and CN Rail official Jim Kane (Liberal) are both pushing to win this working-class riding. Last three elections here have gone Liberal, Tory and NDP.

properties.name: Edmonton-Castle Downs
properties.description: Posted by JournalwebteamIt took a judge\'s recount to decide that Thomas Lukaszuk had won by three votes in 2004, while most fellow city Tories were swept away. 3Landslide Lukaszuk2 now faces the same challenger, Liberal hockey player and welder Chris Kibermanis, who has been door-knocking for three years. The NDP is fielding Ali Haymour, an on-leave Alberta sheriff.

properties.name: Edmonton-Decore
properties.description: Posted by JournalwebteamIn a riding so Liberal it\'s named after a former party leader, Tories have high hopes and some Grits worry about the fate of one-term MLA Bill Bonko. Former Catholic school trustee Janice Sarich is the PC; Bonko himself was a former public trustee. If Ed Stelmach1s coattails are a big asset for the Tories, this riding could switch.

properties.name: Edmonton-Ellerslie
properties.description: Posted by JournalwebteamBharat Agnihotri kept this southern riding Liberal last time by a mere 201 votes. The MLA faces repeat candidates Naresh Bhardwaj (PC) and Marilyn Assheton-Smith (NDP). Tories haven1t held this seat since 1982.

properties.name: Edmonton-Glenora
properties.description: Posted by JournalwebteamLiberal Bruce Miller, a United Church minister, took Glenora in a three-way dogfight in 2004 against a sitting Conservative MLA and the former head of the Alberta Teachers1 Association. His foes this time are less prominent: New Democrat Arlene Chapman, a former federal candidate, and Tory party executive Heather Klimchuk.

properties.name: Edmonton-Gold Bar
properties.description: Posted by JournalwebteamOne of the NDP1s highest-profile candidates is running here, former city councillor Sherry McKibben. But Liberal veteran Hugh MacDonald has proven hard to topple, winning one of Alberta1s biggest landslides last time. Accountant and community centre founder David Dorward is representing the Tories.

properties.name: Edmonton-Highlands-Norwood
properties.description: Posted by JournalwebteamHe has won easily before on his reputation as a bus driver, city councillor and now NDP leader. This time Brian Mason faces a former Liberal-turned-Tory, Andrew Beniuk, whom insiders admit faces a goliath of the left. Liberals are fielding Brad Smith, who placed third in Edmonton-Calder in 2004.

properties.name: Edmonton-Manning
properties.description: Posted by JournalwebteamMLA Dan Backs is seeking re-election as an independent after losing his spot in the Liberal caucus and then the Tory nomination. Longtime Grit organizer and lawyer Sandeep Dhir faces Mill Woods homebuilder Peter Sandhu of the Conservatives. Backs could split the Grit vote, but also the Tory vote with his pro-Stelmach message, while New Democrat Rick Murti may take votes on the left.

properties.name: Edmonton-McClung
properties.description: Posted by JournalwebteamHome of the giant-slayer ‹ Mark Norris stunned Grit leader Nancy MacBeth in 2001, then pharmacist Mo Elsalhy knocked off the junior cabinet minister in 2004. Conservative candidate David Xiao has already proven unable to kill one giant, twice losing his bid to run as a federal Tory in MP Laurie Hawn1s riding.

properties.name: Edmonton-Meadowlark
properties.description: Posted by JournalwebteamLiberal MLA Maurice Tougas1 departure gives Tories hope they can win. Emergency room doctor Raj Sherman is their highly touted candidate, facing off against Liberal Debbie Cavaliere, a former Catholic school trustee. She had bid to fly the Tory banner here, but quit the nomination race days before Sherman won.

properties.name: Edmonton-Mill Creek
properties.description: Posted by JournalwebteamAssociate Minister for Capital Planning Gene Zwozdesky is the consummate constituency man, scooting daily from barbecue to community hall to awards event to four straight election wins (two as a Liberal). Liberal real estate agent Aman Gill came fairly close last time, and is confident she\'ll fare even better in the rematch. New Democrat millwright Stephen Anderson hopes to upset them both.

properties.name: Edmonton-Mill Woods
properties.description: Posted by JournalwebteamLiberal MLA Weslyn Mather is a former school assistant principal and perhaps the legislature1s leading children1s advocate. Conservative Carl Benito came within 518 votes of winning the riding in 2001, but that was when Liberals were at low ebb in the capital. Christina Gray of the NDP chairs the Edmonton Transit System Advisory Board.

properties.name: Edmonton-Riverview
properties.description: Posted by JournalwebteamLiberal Leader Kevin Taft not only doubled his party\'s seats last election, he also personally won more votes than anybody, anywhere else in Alberta. He had the biggest victory margin (6,705 votes) and the biggest percentage majority. This is his castle. Charging valiantly towards him are longtime political players Wendy Andrews of the Tories and New Democrat Erica Bullwinkle.

properties.name: Edmonton-Rutherford
properties.description: Posted by JournalwebteamEven members of other parties admit Rick Miller is one of the sharper Liberal MLAs. Up against him are ministerial aide Fred Horne for the Conservatives and Mike Butler of the NDP, entering politics as a social advocate after his wife was murdered last year.

properties.name: Edmonton-Strathcona
properties.description: Posted by JournalwebteamBased on their voting record, Strathcona residents will miss having former NDP leader Raj Pannu as MLA. He1s retiring after three terms. Stepping into his shoes is labour lawyer Rachel Notley. Other parties realize the legacy of her father, late NDP leader Grant Notley, casts a long shadow here. Legislature staffer Hughena Gagne was supposed to represent the Tories, but dropped out before the election started. Restaurant owner Tim Vant is running for the Liberals.

properties.name: Edmonton-Whitemud
properties.description: Posted by JournalwebteamWinning three straight elections as an Edmonton Tory is no easy task. Can Health Minister Dave Hancock make it four? This bedroom riding is Edmonton1s fastest growing, which means a whole lot of newcomers with no loyalties to Hancock. Liberals are fielding teacher Nancy Cavanaugh, who has been campaigning since last spring, while the NDP have Hana Razga, a recent Ward 4 city council candidate.

properties.name: El Rancho
properties.description: Posted by JournalwebteamThe El Rancho Restaurant, situated next to the much-maligned 118th Avenue, is one of my absolute favourite places in Edmonton. Read more

properties.name: Fort Saskatchewan-Vegreville
properties.description: Posted by JournalwebteamThey went by the busload in 2006 to back hometown boy Ed Stelmach in his successful Conservative leadership bid, and odds are the premier won\'t have to do much door-knocking here to retain his seat.

properties.name: Foster Boy
properties.description: Posted by JournalwebteamVictim: Three year old foster boyAccused: A 32-year-old woman who cannot be named has been charged with second-degree murder, assault causing bodily harm, child abandonment and failng to provide the necessities of life.

properties.name: Foster Boy
properties.description: Posted by JournalwebteamVictim: Three year old foster boy - can\'t be identifiedDate: Found on January 27Location:P atricia HeightsAccused: 32-year-old foster mother - can\'t be identifiedRead more

properties.name: Fringe Festival - various closures
properties.description: Posted by JournalwebteamThursday August 16 to Sunday, August 26 Due to the Fringe Festival the following road closures will be in effect: 104 Street northbound 82 Avenue to 85 Avenue (total closure)83 Avenue and 84 Avenue from Gateway Boulevard to 104 Street (total closure)85 Avenue east of 104 Street (total closure)In addition, there will be a 30-km/h zone in effect on Gateway Boulevard and 104 Street from 82 Avenue to Saskatchewan Drive. Motorists are advised to drive with caution during these dates due to higher than normal volumes of pedestrian traffic around the Fringe Festival Site

properties.name: Hans Alberts
properties.description: Posted by JournalwebteamVictim: Hans Alberts, 77Date: April 16Location: Jasper gates Square - 149th St. & Stony Plain Rd.Accused: No suspectsRead more

properties.name: Highlands shops
properties.description: Posted by JournalwebteamThere is a sauntering, summer afternoon pace to this miniature main street in Highlands, the historic neighbourhood in northeast Edmonton. A short walk to the south, along streets shaded by tall trees and grand homes, is lovely Ada Boulevard. To the north, along similarly appointed streets, is 118th Avenue, once the main eastern route into Edmonton, now a road of grit and promise.Read more

properties.name: James Douglas Foley
properties.description: Posted by JournalwebteamVictim: James Douglas Foley,42 Date: Found on Sept. 4Location: Parking lot beside Clarke Park at 109A Avenue and 92nd StreetAccused: No suspectsRead more

properties.name: Lacombe-Ponoka
properties.description: Posted by JournalwebteamA dark green horse stalks this rural PC stronghold: Joe Anglin, the activist whose landowner group blew the whistle on private investigators hired by the Energy and Utilities Board. The ensuing spying scandal made the board a pariah and Anglin a sort of folk hero. He\'s running as Green party underdog against Ray Prins, a one-term Tory backbencher.

Detour using 156 Street, 178 Street and Anthony Henday Drive as alternate routes.

properties.description: Posted by Journalwebteam Victim: Larry Bosiak, 77 Date: Oct. 26. Location: Clarewood Apartments, 3757 139th Avenue. Accused: Police are investigating Read more

properties.name: Leduc-Beaumont-Devon
properties.description: Posted by JournalwebteamBeing a former Leduc mayor, and plenty affable, helped Conservative George Rogers win in 2004 by double the runner-up\'s votes. Opposition parties were slow to select candidates this time, but they have them now.

properties.name: Leonard Fred Halkett
properties.description: Posted by JournalwebteamVictim: Leonard Fred Halkett, 21, of Sask.Date: Found on May 24Location: 96th St. and 101A Ave.Accused: No suspectsRead more

properties.name: Little Italy
properties.description: Posted by JournalwebteamToday we travel to Little Italy, along 95th Street, north of 107th Avenue. If you\'ve never entered the Italian Centre shop, well, you are poorer for it. If you\'ve never bought a sub sandwich from its deli counter and eaten it in Giovanni Caboto Park -- recently upgraded with a fountain plaza -- you haven\'t lived.Read more

properties.name: Low height - Scona/Connors Rd.
properties.description: Posted by JournalwebteamScona Road/Connors Road below James Macdonald Bridge (low clearance height restriction, northbound and southbound 4.2m) Until approximately September 15 Bridge Construction. Due to construction on the James MacDonald Bridge Low clearance height restrictions are now in effect for Scona Road/Connors Road below James Macdonald Bridge.The free flow lane from Connors Road to the James MacDOnald Bridge will also be closed for approximately 4 to 6 weeks for construction work under the bridge. Truckers use Wayne Gretzky drive as an alternate route.

properties.name: Macdonald Bridge construction

Motorists are strongly encouraged to use other routes to avoid delays.

properties.name: New remand centre
properties.description: Posted by JournalwebteamEdmonton’s new remand centre will be built in the city’s north end beside the existing young offender centre, the provincial government announced today. The 08 million facility — at 127 Street and 186 Avenue — will replace the aging, overcrowded centre in downtown Edmonton. Read more

Expect delays on Groat Road.

properties.name: Sherwood Park
properties.description: Posted by JournalwebteamIris Evans has served as Sherwood Park\'s Conservative MLA, reeve or councillor since 1983, and as a Stelmach loyalist she won\'t back down, even at age 66. Nurse and labour leader Louise Rogers of the Liberals will try a third time against Evans.

properties.name: Spruce Grove-Sturgeon-St. Albert
properties.description: Posted by JournalwebteamHis 599-vote win last time was slim for a Tory outside a big city, but that was before Doug Horner became a senior cabinet minister. Liberal Ray Boudreau will try to narrow that gap in his second attempt. The former Mountie has backing in Spruce Grove, and will bank on St. Albert\'s wavering loyalties to help too. This seat went Grit in 1993 and 1997.

properties.name: St. Albert
properties.description: Posted by JournalwebteamLiberal Jack Flaherty, a former teacher, surprised even himself by painting this town red last election, knocking off the PC incumbent. At age 74, he\'s surprising others by standing for re-election. He\'ll try to keep it Liberal against former city councillor Ken Allred, the Tory candidate.

properties.name: Stony Plain
properties.description: Posted by JournalwebteamFirst-term MLA Fred Lindsay reaped the benefits of backing Stelmach\'s leadership bid, and is now a cabinet minister. That gives him an added edge over teacher Bill Fraser, a Liberal Lindsay easily defeated in 2004. This riding has been Tory since Stan Woloshyn crossed the floor from the NDP in 1993.

properties.name: Strathcona
properties.description: Posted by JournalwebteamSoft-spoken veteran PC MLA Rob Lougheed is leaving politics, so backroom worker Dave Quest is carrying Team Ed\'s banner. Former Liberal leadership candidate Jon Friel will run for his party for a second time.

properties.name: Sunbake Pita Bakery
properties.description: Posted by JournalwebteamThe Sunbake Bakery is in a strip mall, alongside other Arab businesses and cultural organizations. The bakery is run by two brothers, Alex and Geehad Mouallem. They were born in Canada, but spent almost half their life in embattled Lebanon.Read more

properties.name: West Yellowhead
properties.description: Posted by JournalwebteamGruff but popular Conservative Ivan Strang is retiring after three terms, and both the Liberals and NDP will campaign hard in this forestry-and-gas riding they have each held before him. The opposition traditionally banks on labour support, but Tory candidate Robin Campbell heads a coal miners union.

properties.name: Wunderbar Hofbrauhaus
properties.description: Posted by JournalwebteamScooterists beep and wave at each other. Sometimes we go on rides together. Often, we gather at the unofficial scooter watering hole, Wunderbar Hofbrauhaus on Whyte Avenue. Vespa dealer Top Gear, just down the street from the Wunderbar, is scooter central.Read more
